Purpose/Description of the Annual Progress Report:
Annual report, 2009 Joint Project “Strengthening the National Statistical System”
Purpose/Description of the Annual Progress Report:

description.narrative: Strengthening the National Statistical System

participating-org.narrative: UNITED NATIONS DEVELOPMENT FUND FOR WOME

description.narrative: independent political entity

activity-description.narrative: Harmonize national statistics

provider-org.narrative: UNITED NATIONS DEVELOPMENT FUND FOR WOME
UNITED NATIONS DEVELOPMENT FUND FOR WOME

description.narrative: 1. Number of statistical areas assessed towards compliance with international/EU standards in statistics & policy-makers’ needs. 2. Number of methodologies and toolkits (incl. administrative data sources) developed/ revised from the perspective on international/EU requirements in statistics 3. Number of tools focused and actions on “quality of statistical output” developed to comply with European norms and best practices and to build necessary national capacities 4. Number of statistical surveys designed (complying with international/EU requirements) and carried out to respond to policy-making information needs 5. Number of stat.staff whose capacities to collect & produce quality disaggregated data within statistical sample surveys are built, by topics explored, to make more data available for the research and policy development 6. Number of professional development events carried out and/or training materials (curriculum, manuals, guides) for stat.staff implemented 7. Number of user-friendly statistical outputs developed & disseminated, no of areas covered 8. Level of data users’ satisfaction with statistical outputs periodically measured and feedback provided 9. Number of data user capacity building initiatives carried out/institutionalized, topics covered, trainees from Gov., CSOs, media whose statistical literacy strengthened 10. Number of policy documents being assisted with M&E tools (stat.indicators, guidance) to contribute to their efficiency and effectiveness 11. Number of research/analytical papers to analyze less explored topics developed on the basis of available statistics in participatory manner

comment.narrative: 1. Statistical areas are not assessed on compliance with EU requirements/standards 2. Moldovan statistical system still suffers from inconsistent methodologies, multiplicity of data sources, fragmented statistical activities in line ministries 3. Data production systems are not fully covered by the international standards related to quaility of statistical outputs and processes 4. Insufficient number and varity of statistical surveys to cover all the information needs 5. Inadequate resources and lack of continuous training and capacity building for statisticians 6. There are limited opportunities for professional development of data producers to comply with actual requirements and international standards in the field 7. Data dissemination covers only core statistical areas and is done through traditional means of communication; 8. Most of indicators are not disaggregated by sex, age, and geographical territory; and even existing disaggregated indicators are often not disseminated and are not easily accessible which do not meet users' needs and satisfaction. 9. Data users have insufficient skills and capacities to efficiently use statistics for participatory policy-making 10. Government’s monitoring & evaluation capacities are weak 11. Data/evidence-based analysis is poorly applied to analyze the current situation, develop policies, monitor their implementation and evaluate impact, as well as to assess to what extent Moldova is fulfilling its obligations under economic, social and cultural rights.

1. Comparative analysis of at least 2 statistical surveys undertaken to assess their compliance with EU/international standards and feasibility to measure women’s entrepreneurship 2. At least one statistical methodology and 1 toolkit developed to measure entrepreneurship from gender perspective responding to national policy framework and data users' needs 3. Feasibility analysis of Harmonized Set of Gender Sensitive Development Indicators in the context of Government’s reporting on implementation of National Program on Ensuring Gender Equality and its action plan undertaken; data gaps/difficulties/weaknesses in definitions, sources, processing instruments, quality aspects described to be taken into consideration for drafting of a new National Action Plan 4. Not applicable in 2015 5. Knowledge and capacities of at least 5 statisticians to produce new disaggregated data on measurement of women’s entrepreneurship built 6. At least one event organized for statisticians from the East Europe and Central Asia on presentation of UNECE training toolkit for users of gender statistics (in collaboration with UNECE) 7. Results of gender-sensitive statistical surveys disseminated in at least one user-friendly statistical publication (‘Women & Men’), and one e-application responding to data users’ needs 8. Not applicable in 2014 9. Knowledge and abilities of at least 50 data users (Women NGOs, public authorities), strengthened within at least 2 tailored trainings on the use of gender statistics for advocacy and lobbying, evidence-based monitoring and justification of new policies; and within one national dialogue/consultation among policy-makers and statisticians on localizing of SDGs (Goal 5 and other) 10. National strategy on development of statistical system developed; Recommendations on improvement of Government’s M&E activity developed to tackle gender equality and women’s entrepreneurship 11.1. A series of at least 5 thematic data-based analytical briefs related to the

1. Comparative analysis of 2 stat. surveys (on business and Labour Force Survey) plus other 4 administrative sources undertaken assessing their compliance with EU/international standards and feasibility to measure women’s entrepreneurship 2. One statistical methodology and 1 toolkit developed to measure entrepreneurship from gender perspective responding to national policy framework and data users' needs 3. Feasibility analysis of Harmonized Set of Gender Sensitive Development Indicators in the context of Government’s reporting on implementation of National Program on Ensuring Gender Equality and its action plan (until 2015) undertaken; gaps in data, definitions, sources, processing instruments, quality aspects described to be taken into consideration for drafting of a new National Action Plan 2016-20; 4. Not applicable in 2015 5. Knowledge and capacities of 9 statisticians to produce new disaggregated data on measurement of women’s entrepreneurship built 6. One event organized for 44 statisticians from the East Europe and Central Asia on presentation of UNECE training toolkit for users of gender statistics (in collaboration with UNECE) 7. Structure of e-application designed to disseminate gender-sensitive stat. data in a visual format to facilitate the data users' understanding of gender statistics 8. Not applicable in 2014 9. Knowledge and abilities of 140 data users (Women NGOs, gender focal points, CPAs, academia, business), strengthened within 3 tailored trainings (on use of gender statistics for advocacy, lobbying, evidence-based monitoring and justification of new policies, and for media communication), 2 national workshops (on localizing of SDGs, women entrepreneurship measurement) 10. National strategy on development of statistical system developed and publicly presented (49 users, 29 statisticians); Recommendations on improvement of Government’s M&E activity developed to tackle gender equality and women’s entrepreneurship 11.1. A series of 5 themati

1. At least 3 stat. areas assessed towards compliance with international standards to enable the measurement of certain targets under SDGs agenda, including through gender perspective. 2. At least 3 sets of statistical methodologies, questionnaires and software developed to enable data collection in 3 areas which are relevant to SDGs (Goal 10 - Inequality, Goal 5 - Men/Women Entrepreneurship and ICT activity of population) 3. N/A 4. At least 3 statistical surveys designed and piloted in 3 areas which are relevant to SDGs (Goal 10 - Inequality, Goal 5 - Men/Women Entrepreneurship and ICT activity of population) 5. At least 4 statisticians and 5 interviewers benefit of on-the-job training on collection or production of disaggregated data in at least 2 areas (inequality and ICT) 6. N/A 7. One e-solution on gender statistics’ visual dissemination developed and operationalized to improve data use/application for policy making 8. One up-to-date report to assess the users’ satisfaction and information needs developed and presented to the public 9. At least 2 capacity building activities carried out for data users (policy-makers, CSOs, etc.) on at least 2 topics of statistics 10. M&E tools (statistical indicators and methodological guidance) developed to support at least 2 policy documents; Technical guidance and conceptual support provided to at least 3 UN/DP Projects to enable and facilitate the M&E under UNPF 11. 10 profiles on vulnerable groups of women disseminated (in at least 3 formats) making sex

description.narrative: Improving the quality of Moldovan democracy through parliamentary and electoral support
Parliament’s institutional capacity, transparency and effectiveness of legislative structures, systems and processes developed and knowledge of legislators and staff expanded.
independent political entity
Elections - elections

1. Active women’s caucus exists, or increase in activity of caucus that supports legislation for advancement of women. Number of legislative bills passed with gender analysis increased 2. Level of compliance with international human rights instruments of policy and law-making actions and availability and implementation of rules and procedures for cooperation between the Parliamentary Advocates and the Parliament 3. Availability of a revised/adjusted human resource policy in the Parliament, its regulations on the civil servants activity, job descriptions, performance measurement tools etc. 4. Parliament’s Secretariat has developed and implements a Strategic Development Plan 5. Level of participation of citizens in the democratic life through more active outreach of MPs outside the capital/ Number of town/village meetings of the legislators and constituents 6. Availability of systems and processes for legislative research and outreach (information, dissemination and responsiveness to citizen constituents) 7. Percentage of legislators/staff trained on law making techniques, procedures and processes in compliance with the international standards.

comment.narrative: 1. Little or no consideration of gender issues in the legislative process and no dedicated body to address gender equality issues in the Parliament 2. An ineffective parliamentary oversight on human rights. The cooperation between Parliament and Ombudsman institution is rather weak 3. Underdeveloped human resources management system 4. Parliament’s Secretariat doesn’t have a Strategic Development Plan 5. Moldova's challenges to the emergence of a high quality representative relationship between citizens and parliamentarians 6. The legislative and analytic skills of secretariat’s legal and research staff, as well as the MPs, require improvement.

1. Parliament Women Caucus established. 3 Workshops for MPs and staff on gender-responsive budgeting. 2. Guidance and recommendations for strengthening the oversight function of the Human Rights Committee provided. 3. Achieved in 2013. 4. 2015 – 2018 Parliament’s Strategic Development Plan elaborated and approved. 5. Standard Operating Procedures for Parliamentary Constituency Offices developed and approved. 15 staff trained. Parliament Anti-corruption self-assessment conducted. Code of Conduct for MPs developed and approved. 6. 3 Workshops and seminars for MPs and staff on EU legislation approximation, policy impact assessment and financial management and control organized; 40 newly elected MPs receive an Induction training and training on legislative techniques.

1. Women’s caucus established. A training programme on scrutiny of legislation from gender perspective was organised. 30 staffers have been trained. 2. Gender Audit of Parliament conducted. As follow-up, a Gender Action Plan of Parliament 2016-2018 developed 3. A gap analyses of national legislation on human rights performed. A set of recommendations for adjustment of legislation to international human rights standards was developed and provided to Parliament. 4. Anti-corruption self-assessment of Parliament performed. As follow-up the Anti-corruption Action Plan of Parliament 2015-2018 and a Code of Conduct for MPs were developed. 48 staffers were trained on scrutiny of legislation from anti-corruption perspective. 5. SOPs for parliamentary constituency offices were developed. 4 training sessions were provided to 16 parliamentary staffers. 6. 4 Workshops for MPs and staff on EU legislation approximation, legislative techniques and financial management and control organized; 40 newly elected MPs receive an Induction training on law making techniques. 24 MPs have fostered their communication skills and improved their ability to convey core messages via media. 7. A new parliamentary website was developed (official launching December, 2015). The transparency of Parliament’s decision making process increased.

description.narrative: Further strengthening of CEC and CCET professionalism of electoral administrators through trainings and support
Elections - elections

1. Centre for Continuous Electoral Training has improved capacities and training curricula, methodologies and materials, as well as a pool of certified electoral trainers (at least 40) available 2. Electoral reforms supported through provision of expertise and facilitation of dialog and consultations with Civil Society Organisations and general public on the reform actions 3. Political parties finance transparency improved through expertise and training for the implementation of the law on political party financing 4. Central Electoral Commission has a modern population register with an addresses system and inter-operable with other key state registers

comment.narrative: 1. Centre for Continuous Electoral Training lacks basic capacity to organize and conduct electoral training as this is a new institution: lack of training modules, materials, curricula; lack of a pool of professional trainers 2. Electoral reform needed in the areas of electoral administration; electoral systems; voter registration, as indicated in several OSCE/ODIHR reports 3. Law on political party financing absent 4. The State and Central Electoral Commission lacks a modern population register with an address system, integrated with other key state registers

1. Center for Continuous Electoral Training provides training to 20,000 electoral administrators ahead of the local elections 2. Population registration system concept developed 3. Political parties financing reform implementation supported through expertise and training for parties and Central Electoral Commission on monitoring of financing. 4. At least 2 e-registers relevant for the Voters’ Register developed and inter-operable

1. Center for Continuous Electoral Training (CCET) provided training to 11225 electoral administrators ahead of the General Local Elections 2015. Capacities of Gagauz lower level EMB strengthened though trainings delivered by CCET. 2. Preparations for development of population registration concept and support to Civil Status Service (CSS) - ongoing. Strategy for the institutional modernization of the CSS and optimization of business processes – ongoing. 3. Political parties financing reform implementation supported through international expertise. The Central Electoral Commission and political parties’ capacities strengthened during a BRIDGE workshop on Political Financing. 4. Address system draft law finalized after a large consultations with stakeholders. Amendments to other legal acts related to adoption of Address System Law prepared. Technical specifications of Address Register IT system drafted. 5. Technical specifications for other registers drafted (Ministry of Defense) 6. Semantic interoperability in the process of development. Interoperability legal and regulatory framework drafted.

description.narrative: The Project aims to contribute to a more secure, competitive and sustainable energy production in Moldova through targeted support to the most viable and readily available local source of renewable energy, namely biomass from agricultural wastes.

title.narrative: MEBP financial report to the EUD for 2011
MEBP financial report to EUD for 2012
Evaluation of Moldova Energy and Biomass Project

description.narrative: Municipal biomass heating and fuel supply markets established
Energy - power generation
* Number of installed heating systems * MWth installed capacity * Number of installed solar hot water systems * Number of new jobs created * Existence of a quality assurance center (QAC)

comment.narrative: - About 10 heating systems will be either completed or in process of installation in public buildings, with the possibility to produce energy at 22 TJ level. . - About 5 solar hot water systems will be either completed or in process of installation in public buildings. – About 30 new job opportunities will be created in target communities. - Further MEBP II promotion and awareness raising meetings will be held at district/region/city level in 3 areas (I (South), II (North), III (Center) and Transnistria with the participation of around 600 people. - 90 representative meetings on project promotion and community mobilization will be organized with the participation of around 2000 community members. - 90 assessments will be carried out to identify local needs and capacities to implement biomass projects. - 45 participatory evaluations of project proposals will be organized with the involvement of local public authorities, community stakeholders and other community members in decision making process.

. 24 project proposals approved by the Project Selection Committee for the installation of biomass based heating systems and solar hot water systems. 17 heating plants in the process of implementation. 2. Out the 17 heating plants that are in the process of construction and implementation 8 -complemented with solar systems for hot water provision. 3. 1-3 operators for each installation hired operators for maintaining of the installed biomass heating plants. 4. 682 people aware about project activities and possibilities regarding the installation of biomass based boilers in public institutions. 5. 58representative meeting on project promotion and 31 - community mobilization meetings held in the target communities (58 communities).1046 participants benefited and enhanced their knowledge of biomass use and were engaged in development of their communities’ project proposals. 6. 52 assessments carried out in 30 communities to identifying local needs and capacities to implement biomass projects resulting in 37 project proposal submitted to MEBP. 7. 31 meetings with 997 local stakeholders, beneficiaries and communities representatives held.

- About 30 heating systems will be either completed or in process of installation in public buildings, with the possibility to produce energy at 65 TJ level. - About 10 solar hot water systems will be either completed or in process of installation in public buildings. - About 108 new job opportunities will be created in target communities. - Further MEBP II promotion and awareness raising meetings will be held in Transnistria region and new rural communities with the participation of around 350 people. - 25 representative meetings on project promotion and community mobilization will be organized with the participation of around 300 community members. - 25 assessments will be carried out to identify local needs and capacities to implement biomass projects. - 20 participatory evaluations of project proposals will be organized with the involvement of local public authorities, community stakeholders and other community members in decision making process. - Quality Assurance Center Operational

description.narrative: Foundations laid for establishment of efficient household heating and heat supply markets established and private sector demand promoted
Energy - power generation

*Number of annual requests for information on biomass benefits and use received *Number of domestic/microenterprise heating systems installed through subsidy scheme * Number of PPPs established to provide biomass-based heating services to public institutions *Number of pilot projects *Number of new jobs created

comment.narrative: No improved heating systems locally produced, 29 assemblers of biomass boilers 600 households heating systems installed through the incentive mechanism implemented by MEBP 1 active PPP established to provide heating and maintenance services limited number of examples of biomass use in private sector/production processes for heat production, no examples of systematic use of household residues.

- About 100 requests for information will be expected - 250 of domestic/micro-enterprise heating systems installed through subsidy scheme - 2 PPP's established to provide biomass-based heating services to public institutions - Pilot projects: 3 pilot sites identified - 10 new jobs created

. 100+ request for information received from local biomass producers, biomass boilers assemblers and producers, individuals. 2. 250 biomass boilers heating systems for households and micro-enterprises installed through subsidy mechanism. 3. Three (3) PPPs iniated 4.Two (2) pilot projects with Agricultural Colleges/Professional Schools initiated

- About 150 requests for information will be expected - 300 of domestic/micro-enterprise heating systems installed through subsidy scheme - 4 PPP's established to provide biomass-based heating services to public institutions, including one in UTAG - Pilot projects: 3 initiated - 20 new jobs created

description.narrative: Capacity built for growth of biomass markets at regional and local levels
Energy - power generation

* Number of municipal leaders trained. * Number of fuel suppliers trained. * Number of children participating in awareness activities. * Number of specialized Vocational Education Training Programmes on Renewable Energy Sources and Energy Efficiency

comment.narrative: Training and education materials and approaches developed and applied during first MEBP phase

. 17 community leaders from 17 communities from the South region of the country (incl. UTAG) equipped with basic technical, operational and managerial knowledge and skills required for ensuring the sound administration and operation of biomass heating systems installed in public institutions 2. 50 operating biofuel producers with enhanced knowledge and new skills in the field of biomass quality management and solid biomass standards. 21 potential fuel suppliers increased their knowledge and capacities in the area of biomass fuel production. 3. EU Sustainable Week event organized with participants of the Summer Camp “Energel” 2015 edition who organized a Flash mob for raising awareness on renewable energy and energy efficiency. Green-energy festival “Sun Da-I Fest”, National Youth week in Moldova, UN Days in Moldova organized and contributed to the successful implementation of the awareness raising activities. “Green Energy” network added 25 young members. 4. Educational activities on renewable energy use and benefits, including school lessons within the “Renewable Energy Sources”, thematic webinars, discussions clubs, public presentations in communities and to parents-organized in 18 schools from the first beneficiary communities of MEBP second phase and engaged over 1,180 children during 2015 school year. 18 teachers and school principals trained in the area of renewable energy use, didactical methods and techniques provided with “Teachers’ Guide” pertaining to “Renewable Energy Sources” optional course and the students were equipped with the Manual for Children. 5. Bioenergy Camp “Energel” organized and knowledge delivered to 50 most active promoters of renewable energy and wise energy consumption through workshops and practical experiments using wind energy,eco-homes,eco-shows.

description.narrative: The opportunities and benefits of biomass energy for Moldova are well known, visibility of project results is promoted
Energy - power generation
* Increase of positive media references to project * Enquiries to the PMT * Outcome of evaluation surveys

comment.narrative: 1. 300+ Media materials (reports and TV programmes, radio news, newspaper articles, news for web portals and news agencies) broadcasted/disseminated, highlighting the opportunities and benefits of bioenergy for Moldova, project results/activities, success stories of people heating their houses with biomass energy, success stories of schools and kindergartens that moved from gas and coal-based heating to biomass-based heating, and businesses launched in biofuel production. 2.10 public events organized in various formats showcasing the project objectives and results achieved and promoting the green technologies among the people. 3.20 press releases developed and widely disseminated to national and regional media institutions and project partners. 4.6 editions of project electronic newsletters, issued every two months-developed in Romanian, Russian, and English languages and distributed to project partners, media institutions, promoted on social media networks, project and partners web pages. 5. 300+ persons informed about renewables 6.Participants at Moldova Eco-Energetica Award Ceremony acknowledged the significance of the event nation wide.

description.narrative: To strengthen and support the comprehensive efforts to reform the justice sector in Moldova achieving the independence, accountability, impartiality, efficiency and transparency of justice system
populated place

activity-description.narrative: Provide improved conditions for vocational training and occupational therapy for the juvenile inmates

description.narrative: capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Provide support to implement in a comprehensive manner a number of strategic interventions in line with the national priorities for the justice sector reform

description.narrative: Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

1. An integrated e-system for the collection of criminal justice data developed and put in use within the Prosecution Service. 2. Number of prison facilities` staff members covering 100% of prison facilities from Moldova trained on torture prevention and combating standards as per UN Committee against Torture 2010 recommendations. 3.1.Proportion of staff members from Goian Prison for Juveniles trained in application of anger management/violence reduction techniques in the daily interaction with inmates. 3.2. Vocational training workshop established at Goian Prison for Juveniles and equipped with basic instruments and tools to carry out vocational training activities. 4. Quality mechanisms developed in line with ISO 17025 requirements put in place at the National Center for Judicial Expertise.

comment.narrative: 1. Divergent criminal justice statistics due to inefficient data collection mechanism. 2. UN Committee against Torture 2010 recommendations on training of the detention facilities` staff members to prevent and combat torture and other forms of ill-treatment not yet fully implemented. 3.1.Low skills and capacities of personnel from Goian Prison for Juveniles to take over educational/correctional tasks according to the principle of dynamic security: 10% of the staff is well-trained; 50% of the existing personnel have participated in at least one training. 3.2. No conditions for vocational training of inmates at Goian Prison for Juveniles. 4. National Center for Judicial Expertise is not accredited in line with ISO 17025 requirements.

1. An objective e-system for the collection of criminal justice data functional and in use. 2. N/A: Achieved in 2014 3.1. Correctional cognitive programs are applied to 70% of juvenile inmates from the Goian Prison, who have had this problem until 2014. 3.2. Specialized furniture, accessories and consumables are provided for shoemaker workshop. 4. Quality Manual of National Center for Judicial Expertise developed; 5 staff members of National Center for Judicial Expertise trained on ISO 17025 requirements.

1. N/A 2. N/A 3.1 N/A 3.2 N/A 4. General procedure and special procedures in two areas developed and approved in line with ISO 17025 requirements; 5 staff members of National Center for Judicial Expertise trained on ISO 17025 related topics.

description.narrative: Support to the police reform in the Republic of Moldova

participating-org.narrative: US Department of State, Office to monitor & combat Tracking in persons.

description.narrative: capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Support a number of strategic interventions to advance the police reform in Moldova

description.narrative: Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

provider-org.narrative: US Department of State, Office to monitor & combat Tracking in persons.
US Department of State, Office to monitor & combat Tracking in persons.

description.narrative: 1.Number of forensic units of Police endowed with modern forensic equipment for the proper crime scene investigation and evidence securing and Number of forensic staff trained on modern crime scene investigation techniques. 2. One pilot community police station set up and 15 police officers trained in community based policing tactics and their performance. 3.1.1 Enhanced capacities of Police to design and implement reform activities in a number of priority areas. 3.1.2 Number of police staff members benefiting from first hand expertise and knowledge sharing, provided by the international/national advisers. 3.2 Number of public events held in the upgraded conference facilities at the General Police Inspectorate premises.

comment.narrative: 1. Inefficient criminal investigations due to lack of appropriate training and equipment of forensic/crime scene investigation units of Police. 2. Low confidence between the police and the community (26% of respondents trust police, Institute for Public Policies` Barometer of Public Opinion (BOP), April 2013). 3.1 Limited capacities of Police to comprehensively design and implement reform activities in a number of priority areas. 3.2 Lack of appropriate conference facilities to interact with mass-media and general public at the General Police Inspectorate.

1. 3 crime scene vans retrofitted, equipped with crime scene kits and delivered, and 5 staff trained in using modern crime scene investigation techniques. 2. One model community police station refurbished in line with the concept of community based policing, and at least 20 police staff trained on community policing. 3.1.1 Three advisers selected to provide first hand expertise in priority areas to targeted law enforcement bodies. 3.1.2 40 Police staff members benefited from first hand expertise and knowledge sharing, provided by the advisers. 3.2 N/A

1. Seven police territorial units provided with modern forensic equipment for proper forensic investigations. 2. One pilot police station in other district of Chisinau remodeled in line with the community policing principles. 3.1.1 One adviser engaged to provide strategic advice and first hand expertise to Police in priority areas. 3.1.2 20 Police staff members benefited from first hand expertise and knowledge sharing, provided by the advisers in identified priority areas. 3.2 N/A

description.narrative: Strengthened national institutional and technical capacity contributes to an improved National GHG Inventory System; the implementation of NAMAs in the context of national development; and their monitoring, verification and progress reporting

title.narrative: Project Document_Low Emission Capacity Building Programme

description.narrative: Strengthened national institutional and technical capacity contributes to an improved National GHG Inventory System; the implementation of NAMAs in the context of national development; and their monitoring, verification and progress reporting
independent political entity

Preparation phase: 1. Stocktaking exercise and stakeholder consultations undertaken 2. Project proposal prepared and submitted
Implementation phase: 1. NIS institutionalized through a legislative/normative act 2. Number of BAU scenarios developed for selected NAMAs sectors and prioritized NAMAs submitted to UNFCCC 3. MRV system to support the implementation of NAMAs and LEDS in place

comment.narrative:
Preparation phase: 1. No stakeholders consultation conducted 2. No project proposal available
Preparation phase: 1. Some elements of the NIS in place, as described in SNC and NIR 2. LEDS contains a prioritized list of NAMAs 3. Some elements of the MRV system to support the NAMAs implementation and evaluation are known

1. The zero order draft of the legislative / normative act on setting-up the NIS is developed 2. Seven BAU scenarios revised for the selected NAMA sectors and 15 NAMA fact sheets prepared 3. Potential MRV system analyzed for Moldova and discussed with stakeholder

1. The GD on organization and development of the NIS system and Guide for NIS implementation available, 2. Four NAMAs in energy, buildings, waste and forestry prioritized and under preparation 3. The MRV Concept for NAMAs developed and consulted with stakeholders

1. Capacities of national experts and institutions for GHG Inventory in the energy and LULUCF sectors enhanced 2. Number of NAMAs proposals developed and submitted to the NAMAs Registry 3. Institutional and individual capacities for a reliable MRV for NAMAs and LEDS increased

description.narrative: The Clima-East Programme is a partnership on biodiversity and climate change intending to demonstrate that ecosystems can have a strong, positive and cost-efficient effect on climate change mitigation and adaptation.

The project will demonstrate a natural resource management model in the pastures and forest of Moldova which increases ecosystems capacity to sequester carbon while at the same time retain biodiversity and economic values.
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

1. Number of communities and hectares of pastures managed according to the pasture management plans. 2. Number of hectares of community forests managed according to the forest management plans. 3. Number of hectares of pastures land restored using economic valuable species. 4. Number of hectares of community degraded lands afforested using native species as lead species (oak, linden, field maple, ash, elm, cherry, poplar, willow). 5. Monitoring system in place consisting of a) ecological integrity of the grassland ecosystem (richness and density of indicator species populations, such as indicator species (Festuca valesiaca, Bothriochloa ischaemum, Stipa capillata, Poa bulbosa, Poa angustifolia, Artemisia austriaca)). b) volume of biomass growth for forest ecosystems c) carbon dividends 6. Number of people involved in the capacity building and awareness activities at the national, regional and local levels. Increased level of understanding about sustainable grassland, forest management and climate change risks.

comment.narrative: 1. No communities (0 ha) with pasture management plans in place. 2. 0 ha of community forests with management plans 3. Degraded pasture on the most of the park territory 4. No degraded lands afforested on the park territory. 5. No monitoring system in place. 6. Insufficient trainings and awareness in sustainable grassland and forest management

1. 18 pasture management plans for 5890 ha of pasture broadly consulted with pasture owners and users and put in practice 2. Forest management plans provided to beneficiaries and appropriate guidance for their implementation ensured on 1,392 ha 3. Monitoring of pasture restoration grants ensured for their proper and timely implementation on 472 ha of allocated lands. 4. Completion, management, guarding and protection of forest plantations established on 150 ha of degraded lands in order to ensure the 78% overall survival of plantings according to the forestry technical norms for Orhei region. LPA’s participation ensured in plantations guarding and protection. 5. Keep up with the latest carbon monitoring tools, practices at the global and regional level in order to update the developed Carbon Monitoring Database, under the project. 6. A training programme in sustainable grassland and forest management developed and delivered for local communities, farmers, leaders of farmer association and other key groups; exchange of information on successful practices in pasture restoration and management in cooperation with other relevant initiatives ensured at both national and regional level

1. Draft version of pasture management plans developed, broadly consulted with pasture owners and users and submitted to local communities for approval 2. Forest management plans for 1,392 ha provided to beneficiaries and appropriate guidance for their implementation ensured through relevant workshops, meetings and local events 3. Pasture restoration grants monitoring on 472 ha of allocated lands ensured through field visits and trainings 4. 150 ha of degraded lands afforested, and all management, care, guarding and protection works and activities performed in time in order to ensure the 78% overall survival of plantings 5. The Carbon Monitoring Database updated according to the latest developments in the field developed and best practices disseminated during the training programme on sustainable grassland and forest management

1. Implementation of the pasture and forestry management plans supported through explanatory meetings and recommendations provided. 2. A detailed assessment of the real socio-economic benefits (for LPAs and land users themselves) performed and innovative incentive measures (including financial) proposed to support sustainable approaches for land management. 3. Monitoring of pasture restoration grants ensured for their proper and timely implementation on 472 ha of allocated lands. 4. Completion, management, guarding and protection of forest plantations established on 150 ha of degraded lands in order to ensure the 78% overall survival of plantings according to the forestry technical norms for Orhei region. description.narrative: The project will support Moldova with the National Adaptation Planning process which fosters the system and capacities for medium-to long term adaptation planning and budgeting.

The goal of the project is to ensure that Moldova has a system and capacities in place for medium- to long term adaptation planning and budgeting, with the aim to reduce vulnerability of population and key sectors to the impacts of climate change.
independent political entity

Indicators: 1. Number of plans developed or policies, plans or programmes adjusted to incorporate climate change risks and NAP process established in Moldova. 2. Number of technical tools, detailed methodologies (by sector) available to support medium- to long-term adaptation planning in all key sectors, across sectors and at national levels and % of sectoral planners at national and regional/local level trained (gender-disaggregated); policy- and decision-makers have increased knowledge and skills necessary for addressing climate change adaptation in planning and budgeting and # of institutional partnerships established; 3. Data management and service quality in SHS improved; number of adaptation interventions implemented; number of adaptation interventions in the pipeline’ and number of case studies and lessons learned developed by the project

comment.narrative: Baseline 1: The country lacks capacity, data, expertise, institutions and financial resources to undertake medium- to long -term orientated adaptation planning. Institutional structures for mainstreaming climate risk into policy targets are lacking and financial allocations to support adaptation planning and implementation are not made through the national and sector budgeting processes. Institutional mechanisms for cross-sectoral coordination and planning are weak and no communication and outreach strategy in support of medium- to long-term adaptation planning are in place. Baseline2: Knowledge and methodology on a coherent NAP process is not present in Moldova. Relevant government entities and other stakeholders have limited knowledge of available tools and methods to support their effort in advancing to medium- to long-term adaptation planning processes in the context of their development strategies. While climate change mainstreaming is foreseen in the draft NAS, policy guidance for integrating climate change adaptation into national and sector development planning is not yet applied. Guidance for assessing and designing adaptation actions is fragmented and weak in methods to cost, prioritise and design programmes covering key sectors and targets, and linking them to the national budget process. The government entities have limited institutional partnerships with global and regional knowledge management institutions and other governments in place to strengthen capacities for medium- to long-term adaptation planning and coordination. Baseline 3: A number of priority adaptation interventions have been identified through National Communications and NAS, however, linkages to the national/sub-national budget processes are not established and financial resources are limited or not available to implement them or even to conduct feasibility studies. Mechanisms to systematically identify and mobilise national and international financing are not in place. Costs for pre

Output 1 T3. Climate change adaptation mainstreamed into 2 policy documents of energy and transport sectors and 2 sector specific adaptation policy documents in health and silviculture sector developed T.4.National NAP roadmap developed, approved and under implementation. Output 2 T5.Guides for at least 3 priority sectors and related resource materials developed and distributed through workshops and existing knowledge dissemination channels. T6.At least 70% of relevant planners trained in mainstreaming climate change adaptation considerations into policy documents (out of which at least 50% women). T7.At least 70% of planners trained confirm increased knowledge and skills. T.8. Two partnerships under development. T.9. Data management and service quality in SHS improvment started. Output 3 T10. At least 5 climate change adaptation interventions designed and under implementation. T11. At least 10 climate change adaptation interventions in the pipeline

T3. CCA measures developed and proposed to sectors for mainstreaming into sectoral development strategies of energy and transport sectors. CCA Strategy and its affiliated Action Plan for health sector developed and passed 1-st round consultation with stakeholders. CC Strategy of Forestry sector and its affiliated Action Plan developed and passed stakeholders’ consultation. T.4.NAP Roadmap developed. Concept of Climate change Adaptation Coordination Mechanism developed. General Concept of Monitoring and Evaluation component developed. T5. Guide on Mainstreaming Climate Change into Moldova´s Plans, Policies and Strategies for sectors of Moldova developed. T.6. Chiefs of Policy monitoring and development departments of key Ministries trained on screening policy documents against Climate Risks and Opportunities, and mainstreaming Climate Change Adaptation into sectorial planning undertaken. District level decision factor information workshop on the need and modalities to incorporate CCA into local development policies undertaken. T7.Trained planner confirmed their increased knowledge. Trainings survey conducted. T.8. Institutional partnership between SHS and ZAMG on-going. Roadmap to SHSM MeteoAlarm to become a member under implementation. Civil Protection Service of Moldova and Austrian Agency for Civil Protection partnership on-going in order to increase performance of the exercise of civil protection standards. Civil protection exercise simulating climate disaster undertaken. T.9 SHSM staff basic training for nowcasting and forecasting undertaken at ZAMG, Vienna; IT SHSM staff training undertaken at ZAMG, Vienna. SHSM staff training undertaken in Chisinau, Moldova. T.10. Seven (7) climate change interventions designed, under implementation. T.11.Ten (10) climate change adaptation interventions in the pipeline (project fiche and/or feasibility study under development). T.12. Three (3) Lessons Learned developed.

activity-description.narrative: ToT for Civil Protection Personnel and NGO's representatives on Community Disaster Risk Management; Capacity Building and support for Civil Protection and Emergency Situations Service

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Number of policy documents elaborated by the project. 2. Number of decision makers with raised capacities on the disaster risk management actively participating in the national consultations. 3. DRR and gender aspects mainstreamed into CPESS Training Center curricula and and schools/universities educational programs. 4. Number of selected rural communities targeted by Early warning solutions (EWS). 5. Number of innovative IT solutions piloted in a selected town.

comment.narrative: 1. No Comprehensive National Disaster Risk Management Policy Framework in place. 2. Decision makers from the key agencies not familiar Disaster risk management approach. 3. Disaster Risk Management curricula of Civil Protection and Emergency Situations Service (CPESS) training centre not in line with the international concepts applied in DRM and not gender sensitive. 4. No rural communities with early warning solutions. 5. Less than 20 local plans in place which fully integrated climate change and DRM. 6. No innovative IT solutions in DRM implemented in the country.

1. National Disaster Risk Management Strategy and Action Plan is consulted with the national stakeholders via official mechanism and is submitted for the governmental approval. 2. At least 20 CPESS staff have increased knowledge in planning, budgeting, implementation and monitoring of DRM initiatives. 3. At least 2 ToTs based on elaborated Curricula in Community Disaster Risk Management are conducted. 4. Selected 2-4 communities are piloting early warning solution. 5. The prototype of ICT solution/mobile application is developed and starts implementation in the target town.

1. National Disaster Risk Management Strategy and Action Plan consulted with the Civil Protection and Emergency Situations Service and the main stakeholders, submitted for government approval. 2. 33 CPESS stuff and 17 representatives from main national stakeholders with increased knowledge on risk assessment and in planning, budgeting, implementation and monitoring of DRM initiatives. 3. 2 ToT conducted for representatives of the CPESS, main national stakeholders and NGOs on community DRM 4. Selected 3 communities piloted early warning solutions. 5. The prototype of Risk Management portal, ICT solution for increased Ungheni city resilience developed, under implementation.

independent political entity

activity-description.narrative: Innovative SMEs receive support in terms of trainings and grants to pilot innovative projects.

comment.narrative: 1. No tailored consultancy and training on implementation of innovative business solutions are available on the local market 2. Graduates of business incubators have no access to trainings on business innovations 3. Entrepreneurs have no access to a collaborative space for testing their innovative solutions 4. Local entrepreneurs have no access to an innovative small matching grants scheme to promote their innovative projects 5. Limited number of innovative jobs created annually on the local market

1. Up to 50 entrepreneurs get specialized mobile consultancy on what innovative solutions to business development could be applied, support towards the implementation of already tested innovative solutions 2. Up to 25 graduates of the business incubators get tailored training on applying innovative business development (outside of the Innovations Lab) 3. Up to 20 entrepreneurs directly benefit from the Business Innovations Lab to test their ideas 4. Up to 15 small matching grants provided to existing private business for the implementation of business ideas tested in the Business Innovations Lab 5. Up to 50 innovative jobs created at local level

1. 153 Moldovan SMEs got tailored trainings on topics related to the promotion of innovation 2. 10 SMEs graduates of the business incubators actively participated to LED trainings 3. Business Innovation Lab will be launched in early 2016 4. Up to 62 companies start benefiting from matching financial support to implement their innovative projects; a Randomized Controlled Trial was initiated to evaluate the impact of the Innovation Challenge Scheme of the Project, particularly in terms of new jobs created, turnover and labor productivity. 5. Data on new jobs created will be available by the end of 2016, when primary data will be collected from participating SMEs that are implementing projects with and without financial support of the Project

1. Up to 50 entrepreneurs get specialized mobile consultancy on what innovative solutions to business development could be applied, support towards the implementation of already tested innovative solutions 2. description.narrative: Mainstreaming Biodiversity Conservation into Moldova’s Territorial Planning Policies and Land-Use Practices
Mainstream biodiversity conservation priorities into Moldova’s territorial planning policies and land-use practices.
Environment - policy, planning and administration

1. Land area for which DSPs and LUPs, that deliver biodiversity benefits outside PAs are developed and under implementation. 2. Number of sectoral regulations and methodological guidelines that facilitate the incorporation of biodiversity conservation requirements into planning and management of land use outside protected areas. 3. Recorded cases of illegal logging. 4. Observance of grazing norms by local land users in all pilot sites. 5. Number of government staff trained in collection of biodiversity information and integration of this into the development and implementation of land use plans 6. Increase in land area outside protected areas where threats to biodiversity from economic activities are controlled. 7. Population of indicator species outside PAs improves at pilot sites. 8. % of local land-users in 2 districts who are conducting economic activities in ecologically sensitive areas and receive in-field training and technical assistance with implementing modified practices. 9. Increase in public finance for biodiversity mainstreaming in land use planning in pilot areas.

comment.narrative: 1. 0 ha 2. Zero sectoral regulations and methodological guidelines that facilitate the incorporation of biodiversity conservation requirements into planning and management of land use outside protected areas. 3. Soroca-17 cases and Stefan-Voda-17 cases 4. 0% of land users observing norms 5. 0 staff 6. 0 ha 7. % of total plant composition in case of fauna; number of colonies and individual in case of flora 8. 0% 9. None

1. An analysis of options and opportunities for biodiversity mainstreaming into DSPs and LUPs conducted 2. An analysis of international legal/ normative frameworks conducted to choose the best options for Moldova 3. Awareness raising events initiated to inform on the value of biodiversity and prevent illegal logging 4. Proposals for amendment of relevant laws initiated 5. Study visits undertaken for central and local government staff to neighboring countries 6. Initiate discussion with local authorities on the benefits of inventory of red list species for increased control on economic activities threatening the biodiversity mainstreaming 7. Pastures' inventory and Forest Management Plans initiated to enable improving of population species outside PA 8 and 9. Organize a study visits to Romania to increase awareness on biodiversity-friendly economic activities and benefits of investing into this area

1. Two best practices (Belarus and Romania) analyzed, opportunities for biodiversity-mainstreaming into DSPs and LUPs adapted to Moldova 2. Development of national legal/ normative frameworks for each sector initiated based on Belarus and Romania cases 3. Romania study visit to learn about the feasible measures to reduce illegal logging organized 4. Proposals for amending existing legislation initiated (Law on Vegetal Kingdom, Law on Animal Kingdom, Law on land use planning) expected to ensure mainstreaming of vulnerable species, habitats, and ecosystem goods and services; in land use planning 5. One week field visit to Romania (Macin Mountains National Park and Danube Delta Biosphere reserve) organized for 35 representatives of key stakeholders, best practices and benefits of biodiversity-compatible district spatial (land-use) planning showcased 6. Passport approach based on inventory of red list species initiated in Soroca and Stefan Voda districts 7. A comprehensive pasture inventory on 100 ha of pasturelands and Forest Management Plans (FMPs) development initiated for 4 selected localities 8 and 9. Local land-users and authorities benefited from exchange of experience and knowledge during the study visits in Romania for adoption of biodiversity-friendly economic activities and increased targeted public spending

Mainstreaming design-thinking methods across UNDP projects and conduct 5 capacity building sessions for projects’ teams and beneficiaries.

a. Five services were shortlisted for reengineering jointly with State Chancellery and E-Government Center, out of which for two services – Issuing export permits for animal-origin products, and registering/deleting domicile address records - the process of service redesign was initiated. b. Modern School crowd-sourcing campaign with the participation of 2,600 unique users conducted; 50 ideas were submitted and 5 most voted ideas awarded. c. Developed prototypes of a career guidance portal (Cariera Mea), a citizen-reporting tool (Imi Pasa) and piloted and implemented a hackathon for students on developing educational applications (EduSoft). d. Interviews with national experts conducted and results of the interactive survey on the development challenges for Moldova analyzed. e. The second edition of the Innovation in Governance Forum organized, including two parallel practical workshops for public servants involved in either public services reengineering or public policy elaboration. f. Have organized eight capacity building sessions for beneficiaries and staff of the UNDP projects and UN initiatives, such as: JILDP, DRR, CBM, UNFPA, UN Women and the UN Diversity Initiative.

a. Institutionalizing innovative approaches towards Public Service Reform through support to public service redesign (5 services) and to capacity building of the relevant government personnel. b. Apply behavioral insights for the increase of the tax compliance (in cooperation with State Tax Office). c. Finishing the development of the civic reporting platform "Be Responsible" (in cooperation with State Tax Office and Consumer Rights Protection Agency) in partnership with UK Embassy. d. Launch an inclusive career guidance portal for youth – Cariera Mea. e. Support at localizing the SDGs targets in Moldova using crowdsourcing tools. f. Organise the third edition of high-level forum on new governance trends and innovative approaches to public services reingineerinng. g. Supporting mainstreaming innovation in the UNDP’s program design and implementation cycles using Nesta and other innovation toolkits

description.narrative: Strengthening the corruption prevention and analysis function of the NAC

title.narrative: Project Document Strengthening the corruption prevention and analysis functions of the National Anticorruption Center (NAC)

description.narrative: Corruption prevention and analysis function of the NAC
Anti corruption

comment.narrative: 1.NAC Capacity Development and Training Plan non-existing 2.NAC capacity to implement corruption prevention actions as per national and strategic documents is underdeveloped 3.NAC capacity to perform corruption analysis is underdeveloped

1.1. Capacity Development and Training Plan for the Prevention and Analysis Units implemented, 1.2. NAC endowed with modern equipment and specialized software; 2.1. Support NAC in approving the next National Anti-corruption Strategy; 2.2. Carry out the assessment of corruption risks in public procurement 2.3.1. Carry out the assessment of corruption risks in fiscal service and assessment of corruption risks in Chisinau municipality 2.3.2. Support to Integrity Plans drafting at CPA and LPA 2.3.3. Support NAC in Elaboration of on-line training courses for public servants 2.4. Support innovative anticorruption solutions 2.5.1.Support to review, update and implement NAC Communication Strategy 2.6. Awareness of journalists on corruption, ethical reporting raised 2.7.1. Contests for children and students for the best art works promoting zero-tolerance to corruption organized within the National Anticorruption Conference 2.7.2. Support integration of anticorruption issues in school and University curricula 3.1.1. Support NAC in drafting a comprehensive law on the application of wistle-blower and protection of wistle-blowers 3.1.2. Develop Methodology and a Guide on reporting corruption, gifts and undue influences; 3.1.3. Develop an analytical study on corruption phenomenon in judiciary; 3.2.1. Elaborate analytical study on asset recovery and extended confiscation 3.2.2. Support Analytical Unit staff to expose to best practices in EU MSs 3.3. Conduct the assessment on the impact of corruption on women’s opportunities for jobs and career in the central public authorities in line with the UNDP Methodology
